description: From Middle English crasen (“to crush, break, break to pieces, shatter, craze”), from Old Norse *krasa (“to shatter”), ultimately imitative.
Cognate with Danish krase (“to crack, crackle”), Swedish krasa (“to crack, crackle”), Norwegian krasa (“to shatter, crush”), Icelandic krasa (“to crackle”).

entries.meaning: A strong habitual desire or fancy.
A temporary passion or infatuation, as for some new amusement, pursuit, or fashion; a fad.
examples: Winemaking was a huge craze in the 1970s, when affordable package holidays to the continent gave people a taste for winedrinking, but the recession made it hard to afford off-license prices back home.

entries.meaning: (ceramics) A crack in the glaze or enamel caused by exposure of the pottery to great or irregular heat.

verbs.description: craze (third-person singular simple present crazes, present participle crazing, simple past and past participle crazed)

entries.meaning: (archaic) To weaken; to impair; to render decrepit.
To derange the intellect of; to render insane.
examples: any man  […]  that is crazed and out of his wits

entries.meaning: To be crazed, or to act or appear as one that is crazed; to rave; to become insane.
(transitive, intransitive, archaic) To break into pieces; to crush; to grind to powder. See crase.
(transitive, intransitive) To crack, as the glazing of porcelain or pottery.
